title: CVPR_2011_10_abs

sentences.text: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other .
This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition .
This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points .
It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other .
We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors .
We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Entity-reflection_in_image_sequence.label: Reflections in image sequences
Entity-reflection_in_image_sequence.description: Reflections in image sequences refer to a visual phenomenon where multiple layers of images overlap, complicating image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition due to the presence of two distinct moving layers.

Entity-automated_technique.label: automated technique
Entity-automated_technique.description: The automated technique refers to a method for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing the motion trajectories of feature points, effectively modeling reflections as overlapping layers of motion.

Entity-phenomenon.label: phenomenon
Entity-phenomenon.description: The phenomenon refers to the occurrence of reflections in image sequences, where multiple layers are superimposed, leading to challenges in image processing techniques that typically assume a single layer.

Entity-this_phenomenon.label: This phenomenon
Entity-this_phenomenon.description: This phenomenon refers to the occurrence of reflections in image sequences, where multiple layers of images are superimposed, leading to challenges in image processing techniques that typically assume a single layer at each site.

Entity-reflection.label: reflections
Entity-reflection.description: Reflections refer to the optical phenomenon in image sequences where multiple layers of images are superimposed, complicating image processing tasks that typically assume a single layer.

Entity-this_work.label: This work
Entity-this_work.description: This work refers to a research study that introduces an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing the motion trajectories of feature points.

Entity-two_different_layer.label: two different layers
Entity-two_different_layer.description: The term 'two different layers' refers to the distinct superimposed regions in image sequences that are involved in reflections, which move independently and complicate image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition.

Entity-sparse_and_dense_detection_map.label: sparse and dense detection maps
Entity-sparse_and_dense_detection_map.description: Sparse and dense detection maps refer to the visual representations generated by the automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences, which utilize both sparse and dense data to enhance the detection of overlapping layers in motion analysis.

Entity-region_containing_two_different_l.label: regions containing two different layers
Entity-region_containing_two_different_l.description: Regions containing two different layers refer to areas in image sequences where reflections are modeled as overlapping layers that move independently, complicating image processing tasks.

Entity-detector.label: detector
Entity-detector.description: The 'detector' refers to a robust detection system designed to identify reflections in image sequences by integrating multiple weak detection algorithms.

Entity-high_detection_rate.label: high detection rate
Entity-high_detection_rate.description: The term 'high detection rate' refers to the effectiveness of the proposed automated technique in accurately identifying reflections in image sequences, demonstrating superior performance in distinguishing these reflections despite challenges such as pathological motion and occlusion.

Entity-region.label: regions
Entity-region.description: In the context of image processing, 'regions' refers to areas within image sequences that exhibit reflections, characterized by the presence of two distinct layers of visual information that are in motion relative to each other.

Entity-strong_detector.label: strong detector
Entity-strong_detector.description: The 'strong detector' refers to an advanced detection mechanism that integrates multiple weak detectors to effectively identify reflections in image sequences, enhancing detection rates while managing challenges such as pathological motion and occlusion.

Entity-moving_over_each_other.label: moving over each other
Entity-moving_over_each_other.description: The term 'moving over each other' refers to the interaction of two distinct layers in image sequences, particularly in the context of reflections, where these layers exhibit relative motion, complicating image processing tasks.

Entity-motion_trajectory_of_feature_poin.label: motion trajectories of feature points
Entity-motion_trajectory_of_feature_poin.description: Motion trajectories of feature points refer to the paths traced by distinct points of interest in an image sequence, which are analyzed to detect and differentiate overlapping layers caused by reflections in the visual data.

Entity-layer.label: layers
Entity-layer.description: In the context of image processing, 'layers' refer to the distinct superimposed regions in reflections of image sequences that complicate analysis by creating multiple overlapping visual elements.

Entity-several_layer.label: several layers
Entity-several_layer.description: The term 'several layers' refers to the multiple overlapping components in image sequences that represent reflections, which complicate image processing tasks by introducing complexity beyond the assumption of a single layer.

Entity-feature_point.label: feature points
Entity-feature_point.description: Feature points refer to distinct locations in an image that are used to analyze motion trajectories for detecting reflections in image sequences.

Entity-weak_detector.label: weak detectors
Entity-weak_detector.description: Weak detectors refer to a collection of algorithms or systems that individually have limited detection capabilities but are combined to enhance overall performance in detecting reflections in image sequences.

Entity-novel_prior.label: novel priors
Entity-novel_prior.description: Novel priors refer to innovative statistical models or techniques that incorporate prior knowledge to enhance the detection of reflections in image sequences, enabling improved performance in image processing tasks.

Entity-pathological_motion.label: pathological motion
Entity-pathological_motion.description: Pathological motion refers to abnormal or problematic motion patterns in image sequences that can interfere with image processing techniques, particularly in the context of detecting reflections and occlusions.

Entity-motion_estimation.label: motion estimation
Entity-motion_estimation.description: Motion estimation is a computational technique used in image processing to determine the motion of objects between consecutive frames in a video sequence.

Entity-occlusion.label: occlusion
Entity-occlusion.description: Occlusion refers to the visual obstruction or phenomenon that occurs when one object partially or completely blocks the view of another object in image sequences, complicating image processing tasks such as motion estimation and object recognition.

Entity-image_sequence.label: image sequences
Entity-image_sequence.description: Image sequences are ordered collections of images that represent a series of visual data, often used in various applications such as video processing, animation, and computer vision.

Entity-object_recognition.label: object recognition
Entity-object_recognition.description: Object recognition is a computer vision technique that enables the identification and classification of objects within digital images or video streams.

Entity-motion_trajectory.label: motion trajectories
Entity-motion_trajectory.description: Motion trajectories refer to the paths or patterns that moving objects or points follow over time, often represented in a spatial context for analysis in various fields such as computer vision and robotics.

Entity-detection_rate.label: detection rate
Entity-detection_rate.description: Detection rate is a performance metric that quantifies the proportion of actual positive instances that are correctly identified by a detection system.

Entity-image_processing_technique.label: image processing techniques
Entity-image_processing_technique.description: Image processing techniques are methodologies used to manipulate and analyze digital images to enhance their quality or extract useful information.

summary: Reflections in image sequences consist of several layers superimposed over each other . This phenomenon causes many image processing techniques to fail as they assume the presence of only one layer at each examined site e.g. motion estimation and object recognition . This work presents an automated technique for detecting reflections in image sequences by analyzing motion trajectories of feature points . It models reflection as regions containing two different layers moving over each other . We present a strong detector based on combining a set of weak detectors . We use novel priors , generate sparse and dense detection maps and our results show high detection rate with rejection to pathological motion and occlusion .

Predicate-consist_of.label: consist of
Predicate-consist_of.description: The predicate 'consist of' indicates that the subject is made up of or composed of the elements represented by the object. It establishes a relationship where the object represents the components or parts that collectively form the whole described by the subject.

Predicate-causes.label: causes
Predicate-causes.description: The predicate 'causes' indicates a relationship where the subject is responsible for bringing about a change, effect, or result that is represented by the object. It implies a causal connection, suggesting that the occurrence or existence of the subject leads to the development or implementation of the object.

Predicate-fail_as_they_assume_the_presen.label: fail as they assume the presence of
Predicate-fail_as_they_assume_the_presen.description: The predicate 'fail as they assume the presence of' indicates that the subject does not succeed or perform effectively due to an incorrect or unfounded assumption regarding the existence or availability of the object. This suggests that the subject's performance is contingent upon the belief that the object is present, and when this assumption is proven false or inaccurate, it leads to failure in achieving the intended outcome.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject is introducing, showcasing, or making known the object to an audience. It implies a formal or structured communication of information, findings, or concepts, where the subject serves as the source or origin of the presentation, and the object represents the content or subject matter being conveyed.

Predicate-detects.label: detects
Predicate-detects.description: The predicate 'detects' indicates the action of identifying or discovering the presence of a particular phenomenon, feature, or element within a given context. It establishes a relationship where the subject is capable of recognizing or observing the object, which represents the specific entity or occurrence being identified. This connection implies a process of analysis or observation that leads to the awareness of the object's characteristics or existence.

Predicate-analyzes.label: analyzes
Predicate-analyzes.description: The predicate 'analyzes' denotes an action where the subject systematically examines, inspects, or studies the object in order to understand its structure, components, or underlying patterns. This process often involves breaking down the object into its constituent parts and interpreting the data or information it contains, leading to insights or conclusions about the object.

Predicate-models.label: models
Predicate-models.description: The predicate 'models' indicates a relationship where the subject serves as a representation or simulation of the object. It implies that the subject embodies or illustrates the characteristics, properties, or behaviors of the object, allowing for analysis, understanding, or visualization of the object through the lens of the subject.

Predicate-is_modeled_as.label: is modeled as
Predicate-is_modeled_as.description: The predicate 'is modeled as' establishes a representational relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject can be understood, interpreted, or conceptualized in terms of the characteristics or structure of the object. This suggests that the object serves as a framework or analogy that helps to explain or visualize the nature of the subject.

Predicate-models_as.label: models as
Predicate-models_as.description: The predicate 'models as' establishes a relationship where the subject is represented or conceptualized in a manner that aligns with the characteristics or properties of the object. It indicates that the subject serves as a representation or example of the object, suggesting a similarity or analogy between the two. This connection allows for a deeper understanding of the subject by framing it in terms of the object, which may provide additional context or insight.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' serves as a linking verb that connects the subject to the object by indicating a state of being or existence. It establishes a relationship where the subject is characterized or defined by the object, often implying an ongoing action or condition that the subject is experiencing or undergoing.

Predicate-is_based_on_combining.label: is based on combining
Predicate-is_based_on_combining.description: The predicate 'is based on combining' indicates that the subject derives its effectiveness, functionality, or characteristics from the integration or synthesis of multiple components represented by the object. This suggests a foundational relationship where the subject's properties are enhanced or established through the amalgamation of the elements denoted by the object.

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: The predicate 'generate' indicates the action of producing or creating something as a result of a process or function. In the context of the subject and object, it signifies that the subject is responsible for the creation of the object, which can take various forms such as data, outputs, or representations. This relationship highlights the transformative capability of the subject in yielding the specified object.

Predicate-with_rejection_to.label: with rejection to
Predicate-with_rejection_to.description: The predicate 'with rejection to' establishes a relationship where the subject is being evaluated or considered in relation to the object, indicating that the subject's characteristics or performance are specifically assessed while excluding or disregarding the object. This implies a focus on the subject's qualities in the context of the object, often highlighting a distinction or a limitation in the subject's applicability or effectiveness concerning the object.

Predicate-with_rejection_to_(1).label: with rejection to
Predicate-with_rejection_to_(1).description: The predicate 'with rejection to' indicates a relationship where the subject is being evaluated or considered in relation to the object, often implying a focus on the subject's performance, effectiveness, or characteristics when the object is present or relevant. It suggests that the subject's qualities are being assessed specifically in the context of the object, highlighting how the two are interconnected.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a more specific instance or category that falls under the wider classification represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a larger scope or set of characteristics that includes the subject, thereby providing a context in which the subject can be understood as part of a broader conceptual framework.
